journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part A: Journal of Power and Energy

title-group.article-title: Effects of blade exit angle and liquid viscosity on unsteady flow in centrifugal pumps

article-meta.aff: Department of Fluid Machinery, Lanzhou University of Technology, 287 Langongping Road, 730050 Lanzhou, Gansu, People’s Republic of China

abstract.p: Unsteady flows in centrifugal pumps have been extensively studied by means of computational fluid dynamics (CFD) till now. However, effects of viscosity of fluid pumped and blade exit angle on flow steadiness were omitted. Thus, the unsteady flow in an experimental centrifugal pump with two different blade exit angles was explored when the pump handles the liquids with different viscosities by CFD code Fluent to quantitatively clarify the effects in this article. The heads estimated using the unsteady flow model were compared with experiments at two viscosities. The effects of mesh density and turbulence model on the fluid velocity and pressure profiles behind the impeller were clarified. The velocity profiles at the two impellers discharge were validated with the results of laser Doppler velocimetry measurements for water. It was shown that an increasing viscosity of fluid reduces the fluctuation in flow variables at the inlet and outlet to impeller, a larger blade exit angle results in a more remarked fluctuation in the variables.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: It has long been noticed that the blade exit angle of centrifugal pump impeller shows significant influence on its performance, for instance, in reference [1] for water, in references [2–8] for viscous oils. More recently, the study in reference [9] for highly viscous liquids and that in reference [10] for water investigated the effect of blade exit angle with computational fluid dynamics (CFD) codes by employing a steady flow model. It was demonstrated that the CFD technique is applicable for identifying the effect. However, the fluid flow in the pumps actually is an unsteady one which is hydrodynamic noise related [11–17]. In fact, the unsteady flow of water in centrifugal pumps has been tackled, respectively, by the researchers in references [18–26]. However, the effects of viscosity and blade exit angle on the flow steadiness are unavailable.
In this case, there is no chance to understand the effect of blade exit angle on the unsteadiness of flow in a centrifugal pump, especially when highly viscous oils are transported at the moment.

In this article, the unsteady, three-dimensional (3D) flows of water and viscous oil in a centrifugal pump with 20° and 44° blade exit angles were studied at the best efficiency point (BEP) and part-loading point (PLP). The decay characteristics of fluctuation in pressure and velocity heads behind the impeller were quantitatively identified. The estimated head curves and flow velocity have been compared with the measurements and laser Doppler velocimetry (LDV) observations.

The goal of this study is to establish essential knowledge about the effect of blade exit angle on unsteadiness of water and viscous oil flows in the pump to develop an acoustic noise model for optimizing centrifugal pump geometry with a low acoustic level by means of CFD in forthcoming research.

sec.title: 2 MODEL PUMP AND METHOD
sec.p:
The single-stage, end-suction, overhung centrifugal pump with the specific speed of 93 in references [27, 28] for experiment was applied as the computational model. The impeller was designed using the existing mean-line one-dimensional theory in reference [29]. There were two experimental impellers, respectively, with 20° and 44° blade exit angles (Fig. 1(d)). The volute was established by means of the constant velocity approach in reference [29] with rectangular section. Table 1 summarizes the primary parameters of the pump, impellers, volute, and the working liquids in the experiments in references [27, 28]. Figure 1(a) illustrates the geometrical model of the pump with Impeller B generated in Gambit. Fig. 1
Pump fluid domain (a), LDV probe positions (b), survey surfaces and observation points (c), and comparison of blade profile of Impeller B (d) as well as mesh on blades and hub (e) Table 1
Primary parameters of pump, impeller, volute, and working liquids
Item Parameter Value
Pump Flowrate, Q(m3/h) 25
Head, H(m) 8
Rotating speed, n(r/min) 1485
Specific speed, ns (r/min, m3/s, m), ns=3.65nQ/H0.75 93
Impeller A Inlet diameter, d1(mm) 62
Outlet diameter, d2(mm) 180
Outlet blade width, b2(mm) 18
Number of blades, Z 4
Exit blade angle, β2(°) 20
Impeller B Inlet diameter, d1(mm) 62
Outlet diameter, d2(mm) 180
Outlet blade width, b2(mm) 18
Number of blades, Z 4
Exit blade angle, β2(°) 44
Volute Width, B(mm) 40
Throat area, F8 (mm2) 1440
Liquid
Water
Density, ρ (kg/m3) 1000
Kinematic viscosity, ν (mm2/s) 1
Oil
Density, ρ(kg/m3) 851
Kinematic viscosity, ν (mm2/s) 48.5

The head–flowrate curves of the pump were measured for water and viscous oil in reference [27]. The unsteady flow velocities of water at 187 points in θ = 180°, 270°, and 360° sections, shown in Fig. 1(b), were surveyed by applying LDV at BEP (QBEP = 5.79 L/s) and PLP (0.58QBEP) in references [28, 30]. The impeller Reynolds number is Re = d2u2/ V = 2.5 × 106 (water), 3.1 × 105 (oil). In the experiments, the uncertainty for pump efficiency was in the region of 0.76–1.15 per cent, and the total uncertainty of LDV measurement was 5.3 per cent [28].

The LDV system was a four-beam, two-colour (blue and green), back-scattered mode, and two-dimensional (2D) velocimeter produced by TSI. The tap water was used as the working liquid, and the tiny particles in the water were served as the seed particles for LDV. A shaft encoder was installed on the end of motor shaft to record the impeller rotating angle past the measuring volume to establish one-to-one relation between data sampled and the impeller rotating angle. After an ensemble average for the data sampled was conducted by the data processing code PHASE, the unsteady flow velocity in the volute could be extracted. The LDV probe was moved by means of a 3D coordinate traverser. The data sampling and processing were managed with a PC. The unsteady velocity measurements were taken place in θ = 180°, 270°, and 360° sections (Fig. 1(b)).

During the numerical computation proceeding, the averaged total pressure of fluid on the survey surfaces S1, S2, and S3, the torque applied to the fluid by the blades and shroud and hub were acquired at every time step. Meanwhile, the static pressures of fluid at points P1 and P2 were monitored too. Flow variables are uneven across the blade span; however, a maximum fluctuation in them has been observed in the mid-span of blade in reference [21]. Therefore, the pressure and velocity just in this location were recorded in terms of time. The observation points are located at 2, 5, and 10 mm from the impeller discharge in θ = 180°, 270°, and 360° sections.

The flow domain consists of three parts, namely inlet suction pipe, impeller, and volute. Since the unsteady flow simulation in the pump is extremely time-consuming, the mesh size cannot be too small. As a result of this, for Impeller A, the numbers of cells are 25 423 (hexahedral), 174 097, and 160 550 (tetrahedral) in the suction pipe, impeller, and volute. For Impeller B, the number of cells in the suction pipe is the same, but those in the impeller and volute are 137 508 and 225 549 (tetrahedral). Such large numbers of cells, called fair mesh here, are comparable with that in reference [21]. To handle the boundary layer effect, more dense cells were generated around the four blades (Fig. 1(e)).

The unsteady, 3D, incompressible turbulent flow in the pump was numerically calculated by means of Fluent 6.0.12. The standard k-ɛ turbulence model was adopted to account for the eddy viscosity caused from turbulence. The non-equilibrium wall function was chosen to take the streamwise pressure gradient effect on the shear stress on wall into account. The finite volume method and SIMPLE were applied to discretize the continuity, time-averaged Navier–Stokes, k and ɛ equations [31]. Two sliding meshes were prescribed on the interface between the suction pipe and impeller, and that between the impeller and volute. The rotating speed of the fluid domain of impeller was 1485 r/min. Initially, the type of the fluid domain of impeller was chosen to be ‘moving reference frame’, once the computation was converged; it was switched to ‘moving mesh’. An axial inflow velocity was specified at the inlet of the suction pipe according to a known flowrate, and 1 atm was given at the volute outlet as a reference pressure. The rest boundaries were subject to the no-slip boundary condition. The roughness of the wet walls was Ra = 50 µm. In unsteady computations, the time step was 1 × 10−4 s. A second-order implicit difference scheme was used for the temporal term in the governing equations of flow. The convergence criterion was kept to be 1 × 10−4 for all the flow variables.

sec.title: 3.1 Mesh-independent check
sec.p:
To make sure that the unsteady flow field is mesh-independent, a more dense mesh was generated for the pump with Impeller B. This fine mesh consists of 938 044 cells, compared with the fair mesh of 388 498 cells. The velocity and pressure heads at Y = 2 and 10 mm two points behind the impeller, are indicated in Fig. 2 in terms of impeller rotating angle φ at BEP using the standard k–ɛ turbulence model and the fine and fair meshes. Clearly, the pressure and velocity head profiles of different meshes do not seem to show significant difference, and peak values in the profiles are nearly identical for the different meshes. Further, when the mesh gets fine, the averaged pump total head decreases to 10.56 from 10.77 m, causing a 2.0 per cent error. It is believed that the fair mesh is reasonable and feasible to estimate the unsteady flow in the pumps and keeps to be used in the entire computation. Fig. 2
Velocity and pressure heads at Y = 2, 10 mm behind Impeller B against impeller rotating angle φ for fair (solid line) and fine (dashed line) meshes at BEP when pumping water by employing standard k–ɛ model

sec.title: 3.2 Influence of turbulence model
sec.p:
In order to confirm the influence of turbulence model on flow details, the k–ω shear stress transport and k–ɛ realizable turbulence models [31] were switched on in Fluent as well in the unsteady flow computation of the pump with Impeller B at BEP when pumping water under the fair mesh. The two velocity components at Y = 2, 5, and 10 mm behind the impeller in the sections θ = 180°, 270°, and 360° are compared among the different turbulence models as a function of the impeller rotating angle φ in Figs 3 to 5. One can see that the influence of the turbulence model on the velocity profiles is not substantial. It suggests the standard k-ɛ turbulence model is feasible and acceptable in the unsteady flow analysis of centrifugal pump. In the following work, this model keeps to be used. Fig. 3
Velocity comparison among different turbulence models at Y = 2, 5, and 10 mm behind Impeller B in section θ = 90° of volute Fig. 4
Velocity comparison among different turbulence models at Y = 2, 5, and 10 mm behind Impeller B in section θ = 180° of volute Fig. 5
Velocity comparison among different turbulence models at Y = 2, 5, and 10 mm behind Impeller B in section θ = 360° of volute

sec.title: 3.3 Head curves
sec.p:
Figure 6 illustrates a comparison of two pumps head rise curves between CFD computation and measurement at BEP, PLP, and shut-off condition using the fair mesh and standard k–ɛ model. At low flowrates, the head of viscous oil is lower than the experimental observations; while at the high flowrate, the estimated head seems over the measurement. At the shut-off condition, the agreement between CFD prediction and experiment is excellent. In general, the CFD estimation agrees with the tested results. For ν = 1 mm2/s water, the head is over-predicted by 2–10 per cent; for ν = 48 mm2/s viscous oil, the relative error is limited ranging from −10 to 15 per cent between experiment and CFD estimation. Fig. 6
Comparison of CFD predicted pump head curve with measurement: (a) Impeller A and (b) Impeller B

sec.title: 3.4 Comparison with LDV measurements
sec.p:
Figures 7 to 10 present the CFD-estimated and LDV-measured circumferential and radial components of water velocity in terms of impeller rotating angle φ at Y = 2 and 10 mm points behind the impeller discharge in θ = 180°, 270°, and 360° sections of the volute at BEP and PLP for Impeller B. A similar comparison for Impeller A has been made in reference [32]; thus, it is no longer repeated here. The LDV survey was made in references [28, 30] for the two impellers. At these stationary points, because the fluid flow variables periodically follow the impeller rotating angle, the fluid velocity profile just in one circle of the rotation needs to be shown. It can be seen that the circumferential velocity of CFD prediction agrees well with the LDV measurement. Compared with BEP, at the low flowrates, the CFD prediction tends to show less regularity in velocity pattern in terms of impeller rotating angle. Generally, the CFD estimated fluid velocities are consistent with the LDV observations. Fig. 7
Comparison of CFD estimated unsteady velocity components of water at point 2 mm behind impeller with those observed by LDV at BEP for Impeller B: (a)–(c) Vu and (d)–(f) Vr Fig. 8
Comparison of CFD estimated unsteady velocity components of water at point 10 mm behind impeller with those observed by LDV at BEP for Impeller B: (a)–(c) Vu and (d)–(f) Vr Fig. 9
Comparison of CFD estimated unsteady velocity components of water at point 2 mm behind impeller with those observed by LDV at PLP for Impeller B: (a)–(c) Vu and (d)–(f) Vr Fig. 10
Comparison of CFD estimated unsteady velocity components of water at point 10 mm behind impeller with those observed by LDV at PLP for Impeller B: (a)–(c) Vu and (d)–(f) Vr
According to above comparisons, it is confirmed that the unsteady flow model is quite feasible for characterizing the unsteady flow in centrifugal pumps.

sec.title: 4.1 Torque and total pressure fluctuation
sec.p:
Figure 11 indicates the predicted total torque applied to the fluid by the four blades, shroud, and hub of Impeller A and B as a function of impeller rotating angle at BEP and PLP for water and the viscous oil. It is clear that the torque shows a periodic pattern against the rotating angle; moreover, the fluctuation (amplitude) in the torque of viscous oil is less than water. The magnitude of fluctuation of torque on Impeller A seems equivalent to that on Impeller B. Fig. 11
Torque on fluid applied by (a) Impeller A and (b) Impeller B in terms of their rotating angle at BEP and PLP for water and viscous oil

Figure 12 gives the estimated average total pressure in terms of impeller rotating angle at the survey plane S1 near the impeller entrance, and the cylindrical surface S2 close to the impeller outlet under the BEP and PLP conditions when Impellers A and B transport water and the viscous oil. The nearest distance is 30 mm between the survey plane S1 and the blade leading edge, whereas the cylindrical survey surface S2 is behind the impeller outlet with 1.25 mm. Fig. 12
Total pressures at inlet and outlet to impeller as a function impeller rotating angle at BEP and PLP: (a) and (b) Impeller A; (c) and (d) Impeller B

For Impeller A, it is clear that the fluctuation in the inlet total pressure is comparable with that in the outlet total pressure. At the inlet to impeller, when the flowrate as low as 0.58QBEP, the fluctuation of total pressure is cut by half. At the outlet to impeller, the fluctuation of total pressure keeps unchanged with flowrate. For the viscous oil, the fluctuation of total pressure is reduced by 30–40 per cent compared with water.

For Impeller B, a rough and discontinued inlet total pressure profile has been found. It indicates the increased blade exit angle can result in an amplified fluctuation in the inlet total pressure, paying a penalty for suction performance and hydraulic noise level. It can be seen that the fluctuation in the inlet and outlet total pressures at PLP is reduced compared with BEP. Additionally, the fluctuation in the inlet and outlet total pressures tends to become less substantial for the viscous oil at BEP and PLP.

sec.title: 4.2 Pressure and velocity head fluctuation
sec.p:
Figures 13 to 16 illustrate the static pressure and velocity heads of water and the viscous oil against the impeller rotating angle at the two points behind the impeller discharge by 2 and 10 mm in the θ = 180°, 270°, and 360° sections at BEP and PLP when Impellers A and B transport water and the viscous oil. In Fig. 13, at Y = 2 mm point, the averaged velocity head is around 33 per cent of the mean static pressure head for Impellers A and B. The pressure and velocity heads become more uniform with increasing distance from the impeller outlet. The larger distance, the smaller velocity head, and a slightly rising pressure are observed. Since the reduction in velocity head is more than the pressure rise, a mixing loss has arisen. Compared with the velocity head, the profile of pressure head against the impeller rotating angle is uniform except at the blade trailing edges, where a sharp drop is found. A wake behind the blade trailing edges manifests itself with a lower velocity head. Fig. 13
Pressure and velocity heads in terms of impeller rotating angle at BEP for water: (a)–(c) Impeller A; (d)–(f) Impeller B Fig. 16
Pressure and velocity heads in terms of impeller rotating angle at PLP for viscous oil: (a)–(c) Impeller A; (d)–(f) Impeller B

In Fig. 14, the fluctuation of pressure and velocity heads is significantly increased at PLP compared with that at BEP, as shown in Fig. 13, especially at Y = 2 mm point. Obviously, Impeller B with a larger blade exit angle induces a more remarked fluctuation in pressure and velocity heads than Impeller A at the same working condition. Fig. 14
Pressure and velocity heads in terms of impeller rotating angle at PLP for water: (a)–(c) Impeller A; (d)–(f) Impeller B

Compared with delivering water at BEP shown in Fig. 14, for the viscous oil, in Fig. 15, the fluctuation in pressure head is slightly high, but the pulsation in velocity head is considerably suppressed. Also, such a fluctuation becomes even more uniform with increasing distance to the impeller. Fig. 15
Pressure and velocity heads in terms of impeller rotating angle at BEP for viscous oil: (a)–(c) Impeller A; (d)–(f) Impeller B
In Fig. 16, the fluctuation in pressure and velocity heads rises compared with that in Fig. 15 at BEP for the viscous oil. Impeller B still induces a higher fluctuation in both heads.

sec.title: 4.3 Pressure and velocity head decay in volute
sec.p: There are two methods for describing the fluctuation in a flow variable at present. One is to estimate the amplitude or root mean square of fluctuation in blade pass frequency [33]. One is to calculate the amplitude of fluctuation in every harmonic frequency [34]. In the second method, the pressure and velocity head curves in terms of time should be best fitted using a Fourier series to obtain the amplitude of fluctuation of every harmonic frequency. However, the fitting curves always fail to best represent the computed pressure and velocity head curves. Thus, the first approach has to be adopted. In this case, the amplitudes (peak-to-peak) of pressure and velocity heads, Ap and AV are simply estimated from their time history curves.

Figure 17 presents the amplitudes of static pressure and velocity heads of water and the viscous oil versus the distance from the impeller outlet at BEP for Impellers A and B. It is shown that the amplitudes of these flow variables are substantially declined in a distance of 0–10 mm from the impeller; beyond 10 mm, little variation occurs in the amplitudes, suggesting that the wake behind the impeller is significantly decayed in this so short distance. Fig. 17
Amplitude of pressure and velocity heads of water and viscous oil behind impeller at BEP: (a)–(c) Impeller A; (d)–(f) Impeller B

At the same working condition, at the same point behind the impeller, the velocity head fluctuation amplitude of the viscous oil is just around half of water, particularly in the region nearby the impeller discharge. At BEP, the amplitude of pressure pulsation appears to be less affected by viscosity of liquid. However, there is a significant decay in the velocity head.

Compared to θ = 180° and 270° sections, the amplitude of velocity head of water shows a relative considerable increase in vicinity of the impeller outlet at θ = 360° section. However, the amplitude of pressure head is comparable in these three sections. The amplitude of pressure head of the viscous oil does not seem to demonstrate a noticed difference from that of water in the three sections.

Figure 18 indicates the amplitudes of static pressure and velocity heads of water and the viscous oil versus the distance from the impeller outlet at PLP for Impellers A and B. The amplitudes of static pressure and velocity heads are higher than those at BEP. Similarly, Impeller B results in a larger amplitude in static pressure and velocity heads. At PLP, the amplitudes of pressure and velocity heads are higher by onefold than those at BEP, especially for the velocity head. Fig. 18
Amplitude of pressure and velocity heads of water and viscous oil behind impeller at PLP: (a)–(c) Impeller A; (d)–(f) Impeller B

The AV based on the LDV measurement for water is involved in Figs 17 and 18 as well for comparison. The experimental AV always tends to damp slowly behind an impeller, especially in the section θ = 360°, where the volute tongue disturbs its nearly fluid flow considerably in the experiments in references [28, 30]. However, such an effect is somehow under-predicted in the CFD computations.

The decay of fluctuation of fluid variables in a plane wake or in a wake behind an aerofoil can be described by using a power law in theory [35, 36]. Hence, it is assumed that the amplitude Ap and AV yield such a law: Ap∝(Y/d2)-mp and AV∝(Y/d2)-mV. Those power indices can be estimated with the data in Figs 17 and 18. The corresponding results are presented in Table 2. Two indices depend on fluid viscosity and pump working condition. The power for Ap is approximately half smaller than that for AV. From Table 2, it can be seen that an increased blade exit angle leads to a larger Ap and a lowered AV. Table 2
Decay power of amplitude of pressure and velocity heads in two sections of volute for Impellers A and B
Section Index Liquid BEP PLP
A B A B
θ = 270° mp Water 0.3497 0.3732 0.3086 0.4063
Oil 0.3518 0.4776 0.4872 0.5612
mV Water 0.7339 0.6468 0.8108 0.4936
Oil 1.0656 0.9838 0.9298 0.7447
θ = 360° mp Water 0.4975 0.4238 0.4549 0.4859
Oil 0.6844 0.5875 0.6075 0.6606
mV Water 0.8813 0.6468 0.9124 0.4724
Oil 1.0656 0.9642 0.8156 1.0249

The decay power index of pressure is in the range 0.31–0.68 compared with 0.77 in reference [33]. The decay power index of velocity head is in the range 0.47–1.07, and the corresponding power index values for velocity are 0.24–0.54, compared with 0.5 behind an airfoil in reference [36] and 0.51–0.58 behind a 2D airfoil cascade in reference [37].

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The unsteady turbulent flows of water and viscous oil in an experimental centrifugal pump with Impellers A and B were analysed numerically by means of CFD code Fluent. The water and viscous oil head–flowrate curves estimated with the unsteady flow model have been compared with those measured. The turbulence model and mesh size effects on velocity profiles have been identified. The unsteady flow velocity profiles of water near the impeller outlet have been validated with LDV observations. The influences of viscosity of fluid and blade exit angle on the fluctuations in torque and total pressure head have been clarified. The relationships between the pulsation amplitude of static pressure and velocity heads of fluid flow behind Impellers A and B at two different working conditions and two values of viscosity of fluid have been established. The major findings are as follows: (1) the amplitude of fluctuation in flow variables is comparable at impeller entrance and outlet; (2) the increased viscosity of liquid can suppress the pulsation in velocity of fluid behind the impeller; (3) the decay power indices of the amplitudes of pressure and velocity heads behind impeller depend on viscosity and working condition as well as blade exit angle.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This work was supported by Lanzhou University of Technology [grant number 0184].
